*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Premises, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition for business invitees, including the duty to inspect for, discover, remedy, and/or warn of dangerous conditions on the floors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion passage criticizing the continued reliance on common-law categories like trespasser, licensee, and invitee. It does not state or apply a specific duty of reasonable care toward business invitees, nor does it discuss an owner’s duty to inspect, discover, remedy, or warn of dangerous floor conditions. Therefore, this text does not support the detailed duty proposition for business invitees described in the claim.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Premises, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition for business invitees, including the duty to inspect for, discover, remedy, and/or warn of dangerous conditions on the floors.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that a landowner or possessor owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, including an obligation to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers. While the facts of the case concern a highway crossing rather than interior floor conditions, the quoted passage clearly affirms the general duty toward business invitees that encompasses inspection, discovery, and remediation/warning of dangerous conditions on the premises. Thus, the case properly supports the broad duty proposition, though not the floor-specific factual application.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.” Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995).

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A, and 1.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds the minimum jurisdictional amount for civil actions in the Somerville District Court, exclusive of interest and costs, and is within the Court’s monetary jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A, and 19C.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2..proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the cause of action arose in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 166–67 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Alternatively, the size of the spill, the visible cart tracks running through it, and the presence of an employee in close proximity indicate that the Hazardous Condition had existed for a sufficient length of time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it before Plaintiff was injured.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that circumstantial facts like spill size, visible tracks, and nearby employees can show that a hazardous condition existed long enough that the defendant should have discovered and remedied it. Oliveri, however, holds that similar circumstantial evidence (description of the substance and timing of cleaning) was insufficient to establish that the condition existed for a sufficient time, and reverses a plaintiff’s verdict. The case generally emphasizes how often such circumstantial evidence fails to prove the required time element, so it undermines rather than supports the cited proposition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it.… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required. The mere stickiness or adherence of the substance to the step is not such a quality as, in common knowledge, established the time element.”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783–85 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions described herein created an unreasonable risk of harm to customers, including Plaintiff, and constituted a breach of Defendant’s duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts premises liability law.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The case directly addresses the scope of a Massachusetts supermarket’s duty of reasonable care to customers under premises liability, holding that a store may breach its duty where its self-service mode of operation creates foreseeable risks (such as produce on the floor) and it fails to take reasonable precautions. The court adopts the mode-of-operation approach and repeatedly frames liability in terms of whether the defendant’s acts/omissions created an unreasonable risk of harm and whether it exercised reasonable care in view of those risks, which aligns with the proposition. Although Sheehan is about summary judgment and not a final merits finding of breach, it clearly articulates the governing duty and breach standard for Massachusetts premises liability in self-service stores.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “As such, ‘it is necessary in determining whether the evidence was sufficient to warrant an inference that the defendant violated its duty of care to consider “whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred.”’… Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition:
This duty includes, but is not limited to:  
   a. A duty to make reasonable inspections of the premises at reasonable intervals to discover dangerous conditions;  
   b. A duty to timely clean, repair, or otherwise remedy dangerous conditions of which the owner knows or should know; and  
   c. A duty to adequately warn lawful visitors and invitees of dangerous conditions that are known or reasonably should be known, and that are not open and obvious.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly restates the general Massachusetts premises-liability rule that a property owner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, including to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove dangerous conditions or to warn of non-obvious dangers the owner knows or should know about. In doing so, it relies on prior authorities like Mounsey and Kelley and explicitly applies that same duty to snow and ice, which encompasses inspection, timely remediation, and warning of non–open-and-obvious hazards. Thus, it supports the articulated sub-duties as components of the general duty of reasonable care.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….” This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known. … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166\.proposition:
This duty includes, but is not limited to:  
   a. A duty to make reasonable inspections of the premises at reasonable intervals to discover dangerous conditions;  
   b. A duty to timely clean, repair, or otherwise remedy dangerous conditions of which the owner knows or should know; and  
   c. A duty to adequately warn lawful visitors and invitees of dangerous conditions that are known or reasonably should be known, and that are not open and obvious.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166\.support_reasoning: The case abolishes status-based limitations and holds that landlords, like other persons, must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to unreasonable risk of harm, expressly framing the duty in terms of whether the landlord, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered a defect and repaired it within a reasonable time. That directly encompasses a duty to inspect (discovery), to timely repair, and, by adopting general negligence principles and rejecting the hidden-defect limitation, a duty to act reasonably which includes warning of non-obvious dangers known or reasonably knowable. While the opinion does not list these three duties in a,b,c form, its adoption of a general negligence standard for landlords to lawful visitors supports each component of the proposition.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 166\.relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. … Thus, the hidden defect doctrine … has lost its raison d’etre. The question now must be whether the landlord, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered the defect and repaired it within a reasonable time.”

*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.raw_text: *Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.proposition: The employee’s statement that he had noticed the spill “a few minutes ago” before Plaintiff’s fall demonstrates that Defendant had actual notice of the Hazardous Condition and unreasonably delayed in taking remedial or warning measures.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion never mentions any employee statement about having noticed the spill “a few minutes ago,” nor does it discuss actual notice or delay after such notice. Instead, the court finds there was no evidence that defendant’s employees knew of the condition and reverses the verdict because plaintiff failed to show the spill existed long enough for constructive notice. The case therefore does not support a proposition about actual notice and unreasonable delay based on an employee’s statement.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

*Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry.*, 208 Mass.proposition: Even if Defendant did not have actual notice, the nature, size, and appearance of the spill, including visible cart tracks through it, and the presence of an employee nearby, demonstrate that the Hazardous Condition existed for a sufficient period of time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and corrected it, thereby establishing constructive notice.
*Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry.*, 208 Mass.case_name: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.
*Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry.*, 208 Mass.support_reasoning: The court explicitly held that the condition and appearance of the banana peel (dry, gritty, black, flattened, as if trampled) allowed an inference that it had been on the platform a considerable time and would have been seen and removed by employees whose duty was to keep the platform safe. This is a classic constructive notice analysis: even without proof of actual notice, the nature and apparent age of the hazard, combined with an employee’s duty and presence at the station, permitted the jury to find that the defendant should, in the exercise of reasonable care, have discovered and remedied it.
*Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry.*, 208 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The inference might have been drawn from the appearance and condition of the banana peel that it had been upon the platform a considerable period of time, in such position that it would have been seen and removed by the employees of the defendant if they had performed their duty. Therefore, there is something on which to base a conclusion that it was not dropped a moment before by a passenger… It might have been found that the platform was suffered to remain in such condition as to be a menace to those rightfully walking upon it.”

*Uloth v. City Tank Corp.*, 376 Mass. 87.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, as set forth above, falls below the standard of reasonable care that a reasonably prudent supermarket operator would exercise under like circumstances.
*Uloth v. City Tank Corp.*, 376 Mass. 87.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard of reasonable care for a reasonably prudent supermarket operator. Uloth is a products-liability/design-negligence case involving a refuse truck manufacturer and designer, not a premises-liability or supermarket-operations case. The opinion discusses a designer’s duty to use reasonable care to eliminate avoidable dangers in product design and the role of warnings, but it does not address or establish any standard of care applicable to supermarket operators or analogous premises owners.
*Uloth v. City Tank Corp.*, 376 Mass. 87.relevant_excerpt: “In our view the focus in design negligence cases is not on how the product is meant to function, but on whether the product is designed with reasonable care to eliminate avoidable dangers. … We decline to hold that there can be no negligence in design if the product performs as intended, or if there are warnings found to be adequate, or if the dangers are obvious.”

*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was greater than any negligence, if any, attributable to Plaintiff; therefore, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, and holds that in negligence actions a plaintiff’s contributory negligence only bars recovery if it is greater than the total negligence of the defendants. The court expressly rejects the argument that plaintiff’s unreasonable use (which barred his warranty claim) should also bar his negligence claim, emphasizing instead that under § 85 the trier of fact must compare plaintiff’s and defendants’ negligence and that recovery is barred only when the plaintiff’s share exceeds 50%.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.)."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was greater than any negligence, if any, attributable to Plaintiff; therefore, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B (prejudgment inte.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover her damages, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, and compensation for pain and suffering, pursuant to Massachusetts common law and G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover reasonable monetary damages to fully and fairly compensate her for all injuries and losses caused by Defendant’s negligence, together with statutory prejudgment interest and costs, as allowed by law.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable Massachusetts rules and statutes, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
